div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Post, December 6, 1906
div1.p:
President Expresses Hope that Congress
Will Take Suitable Action.

President Roosevelt yesterday sent to
Congress papers relating to the Walter
Reed Memorial Association, with a recom-
mendation that action be taken toward
furthering the plans of the organization.
It was suggested that financial aid be
given the association, but the President
confines himself to expressing “the earn-
est hope that Congress will take suitable
action.”

He said that Maj. Reed's part in the
experiments which resulted in teaching
the people how to cope with yellow fever
was such as to render mankind his debtor;
and that this nation should, in some prop-
er fashion bear witness to this fact.

It was Maj. Reed who first conceived
the idea that yellow fever was com-
municated to human beings by the bite
of mosquitoes. He gave up his life in
proving his theory.
